en.purpose: To evaluate if a patient fits into the Wisconsin criteria.
en.use:
The Wisconsin criteria predicts need for CT use after maxillofacial injury. It is used when assessing patients with facial injuries from trauma in the emergency department. By using this, we can minimize exposure to radiation and costs by avoiding unnecessary maxillofacial CT imaging in cases with a low likelihood of significant injury.

The Wisconsin Criteria is positive if any of the following findings are present: 

Bony stepoff or instability.

Periorbital swelling or contusion.

Glasgow Coma Scale score <14.

Malocclusion.

Tooth absence.
en.misuse:
This tool does not diagnose facial fractures; rather, it assists in determining the necessity of additional imaging.

Since these criteria are based on physical examination findings, results depend on the accuracy of a clinician’s physical examination skills.

The original study population consisted primarily of blunt trauma patients at a single trauma center, which may limit the utility in penetrating trauma cases and affect generalizability.

In the original study, the presence of any of the 5 criteria was 98.2% sensitive for the presence of a facial fracture, with a negative predictive value of 87.8% in the absence of all 5 criteria.

Validation studies show a sensitivity range of 73%-90% and a negative predictive value of 60%-93%.
